abstract.p: Pres Clinton will add brief stop in Cairo, Egypt, to trip to Africa, to discuss Middle East peace talks with Pres Hosni Mubarak (S)

block.p: White House officials said yesterday that President Clinton would add a brief stop in Cairo to his Africa trip to discuss the Middle East peace talks with President Hosni Mubarak.
The two leaders will discuss the latest developments and ways to encourage the negotiations, said the White House's spokesman, Jake Siewert.
White House officials said yesterday that President Clinton would add a brief stop in Cairo to his Africa trip to discuss the Middle East peace talks with President Hosni Mubarak.
The two leaders will discuss the latest developments and ways to encourage the negotiations, said the White House's spokesman, Jake Siewert.

Mr. Clinton arrives in Abuja, Nigeria, today for a two-day visit aimed at buttressing the country's fragile democracy. On Monday, he flies to Tanzania to meet participants in the Burundi peace negotiations being held in Arusha.

The president had been scheduled to return briefly to Abuja on Tuesday to refuel his plane, but officials yesterday added Cairo to his itinerary because Mr. Mubarak will not be attending a meeting of world leaders early next month at the United Nations in New York.
Mr. Clinton will use the United Nations session to meet with both Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

White House aides said Mr. Clinton was eager to meet with Mr. Mubarak as well to help jump-start the peace talks. The president spoke with both Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Barak early yesterday to discuss the Cairo meeting, officials said.

Clearly juggling a variety of foreign policy challenges, Mr. Clinton will travel to Colombia on Wednesday for a one-day trip to lend support to the counternarcotics campaign launched by President Andres Pastrana.
